Tim, I started following you back when it was the tongue-in-cheek photos in the space suit. I like the way you have evolved your content. The Dragon interior is indeed stunning. I'd be curious to know about the interior designers who are creating these craft.

Already been following it since the beginning! Several years back, watching all the updates about what would be occurring, from re-purposing the rockets, to the "futuristic" suits etc.. If you don't have an appeal for space exploration, then that statement will make NO sense. There are several private companies vying to explore outside of our planet: Bigalow Aerospace, Mars One Mission (who I saw as the original idea behind space exploration back in 2009), Blue Origin, and a couple others. All these companies are private companies, not governmental like NASA.

I rest a bit better knowing that humanity continues to reach for the stars, explore more, (especially after learning the most we can about our own planet), and hopefully bring everyone together (though it won't work in uniting the world). To know it continues to be sought after...that makes me hopeful for the future.

There's no chance the astronauts just "hang out", think to themselves "oh, it's just going to jettison the nose-cone in a second" and are just trained purely for contingencies.  This has been a misconception about the aviation industry for years, i.e. you just push a button and sit back and relax.  There is so much procedural work to go through at critical phases of flight and these kind of comments just demean their jobs and skill level.  One day it will be like that and the tecnology has probably been good enough for some time now but it's certainly not implemented to that extent in aviation and at this early stage of Space X I imagine they're VERY busy during the launch phase.  When the astronauts say they're "monitoring" it doesn't just mean they're sat there waiting for something to happen, there will be very specific things they have to work through and communicate.  It's a good video but these comments are quite naive and patronising.

Hands off "autonomous" space flight is not a "21st century way of having a spaceship".  Both the US and Russian original designs and hardware were computer controlled or "flown" from the ground.  The US astronauts had to fight for flight controls and did so because of their test pilot backgrounds.

The touchscreen and "capacitive buttons" worry me. A spacecraft during liftoff and reentry will be vibrating and have high G loads. I'd want a physical button I can touch without triggering, then just apply more pressure to trigger. No uncertainty. No "well, I THOUGHT my finger was on 'deorbit now', but it actually activated 'cabin depress' - oops." (1:34 - they're right next to each other!)

It doesn't need hundreds/thousands of physical buttons - just replace the capacitive buttons with physical ones. They can even change what they do, with a label on the screen right above. Sort of how airliners don't use touchscreens, they use plain screens with buttons surrounding them that change in software what they do. You should be able to push buttons by *feel*, not needing to look directly at them.

@04:09 "The next two NASA missions will only have two seats."

While the first crewed mission, DM2 (Demonstration Mission 2), will only have two seats, the second crewed mission, PCM 1 (Post Certification Mission 1), will have four seats. It will fly two NASA astronauts (Michael Hopkins & Victor Glover), one USOS international partner (Europe/ Canada / Japan) astronaut, and one Russian cosmonaut.

First of all, extreme awesome insights!
But on two points I want to calm your excitement with a bit of context ...

1. Autonomy isn't really new 21st century tech: every Russian-human-space-flight-vehicle (Vostok, Soyuz, Buran, TKS, Salyut) is/was capable of fully autonomous flight, starting with Jury Gagarin. But true, for American crafts this is kind of new... trolling

2. The seats going up to the controls is also an commonly used technique (Shenzhou, Soyuz, ...) to dampening the shock of landing or firing launch-abort-motors.
